column1: A very severe infection may cause neutrophils to be used up quickly, and may also prevent the bone marrow from producing more neutrophils.
Some disorders in the pregnant mother, such as preeclampsia, can also lead to neutropenia in infants.

In rare cases when the neutrophil count is low enough to be life threatening, the following treatments may be recommended: - Medicines to stimulate white blood cell production - Antibodies from donated blood samples (intravenous immune globulin)
Some infections and other conditions in newborns can be life-threatening.
However, most infections usually do not cause long-term side effects after the neutropenia goes away or is treated.
